history.content:
Dear Students, 

Have you every had those moments when you forget you are not working in command line?


SURF THE WAVES with ASSET

ASSET:ADVANCED SECURED SENSOR ENABLING TECHNOLOGIES

  The application deadline is April 6, 2018 or until positions are filled

Funded by NSF and DoD (PIs: Dr. Pissinou and Dr. Iyengar)

The Summer 2018 REU SITE of Florida International University Research Experience for Undergraduates in Advanced Secured Sensor Enabling Technologies spans ten weeks, May 29- August 4 2018, offers research and professional development opportunities for 10 undergraduate students.

Available research projects share the theme of advanced secured sensor enabling technologies and span several exciting areas such as

   * Trajectory Privacy Preservation in Mobile Sensor Networks,
   * Privacy & Secure Social Sensor Networks,
   * Mobile Video Authenticity Verifications
   * Search Rank Validation for Social Media
   * A Software Library for Visualizing Large Scale Sensor Network Applications,
   * Trajectory Sensor Stream Cleaning,
   * Resource Management for Security & Surveillance over a Sensor Network,
   * Self-configuring, non-cooperative Mobile Sensors

and many others

Details about REU-ASSET including an online application, can be found at http://it2.fiu.edu/it2_REU.php  and this flyer. The application deadline is April 6, 2018 or until positions are filled.

Spark @ Cal

The Student Technology Council presents its second showcase, Spark: A Student Tech Fair, on March 13th, at Anna Head Alumnae Hall. Students will have a chance to learn about new developments and engage with innovation groups on campus and from our 2 speakers. Light refreshments provided!

 

Register on Eventbrite now to enter to win a prize drawing for one of 4 $25 Gift Cards, an Amazon Echo Dot, or a Dell Backpack + Power Companion.

 

Speakers:

Caroline Winnett, Executive Director of SkyDeck

Dennis Zhao, Twitter APM

 

FB Event: https://www.facebook.com/events/1579788915410313/

Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/spark-cal-a-student-tech-fair-tickets-41539290135

​Jengyee Liang Scholarship/Prize

Leadership For A Better World. This prize was established in honor of the memory of Jengyee Liang, who received her B.S. in 2005 from IEOR. The $2,​000 prize recognizes well-rounded undergraduate students throughout the University of California, Berkeley for their exceptional leadership in working to better the world. The winner was chosen by an ​IEOR ​ad hoc committee who considered leadership experience, GPA, and an original essay.

 

Additional information about this scholarship/prize in honor of IEOR alum, Jengyee Liang is listed here.

 

The application deadline is April  10 at 4pm. Please contact Anayancy Paz

​at anayancy@berkeley.edu ​if you have questions.

Squishy Robotics

Squishy Robotics is a new startup based in Berkeley, CA that focuses on developing novel, shapeshifting soft robots called /tensegrity/ robots, built on research from UC Berkeley’s Emergent Space Tensegrities lab in collaboration with NASA Ames. We specialize in developing low-cost, compliant, and robust robotic systems to help reduce risk to first responders during emergency response, disaster relief, and search and rescue applications.

 

Squishy Robotics is currently seeking highly motivated interns to help our company grow towards our vision of delivering novel and impactful technology to first responders. Internships include regular mentoring/professional development opportunities in both technology and business development with esteemed UC Berkeley faculty and doctoral students, along with the opportunity to be part of the innovative ecology at SkyDeck, UC Berkeley’s official start-up accelerator!

 

We are seeking:

  • Mechanical Engineers

  • Electrical/Mechatronics Engineers

  • UI designers

  • Social Media and Communications Manager

  • Software Engineers

  • Controls Engineers

 

*How to apply:*Please send email to info@squishy-robotics.com <mailto:info@squishy-robotics.com> with your resume and portfolio of prior work. *Please put this in the subject line:* Internship Application – [position] (e.g., Internship Application – Mechanical Engineer)

 

More in the attached flyer and at Squishy Robotics website: https://squishy-robotics.com/

Cal Energy Corps Internship Opportunity

Launched in 2011, the program provides students with hands-on experience in the non-profit and private sectors to enhance their academic work; giving them a chance to contribute their talents to real-world projects. Students chosen for the program participate in full-time 8+ week internships over the summer at selected host organizations, receiving a $600 per week living stipend and structured mentorship. Following the program, students present their research projects in the Cal Energy Corps Symposium to the university community and the public.

 

This year, placements are available at the Center for Carbon Removal, Imprint Energy, Clarity Movement Co. (an environmental tech startup out of the CITRIS Foundry), Power Standard Labs, and the Lawrence Berkeley National Lab; as well as abroad with Tec De Monterrey, in Mexico.

 

For more information, including how to apply, please visit their website at calenergycorps.berkeley.edu. Applications due March 30, 2018.

Comp Lit Summer R1B and AC courses

If you are looking for a summer R1B or AC course, we have you covered in Comp Lit!  We have two R1B and four 60AC courses, including our new online one (W60AC), so you can get your AC requirement done even if you are not in Berkeley this summer.  I include the info and some of the posters below; all are session D (July 2-August 10) except for the online course, which is session C (June 18-August 10).

 

1.  R1B.001:  Sea Changes in Film and Poetry (Instructor:  Simona Schneider) TWTh 1-3:30

2.  R1B.002:  Celebrity Status:  The Art of Being Famous (Instructor:  Johnathan Vaknin) TWTh 10-12:30

3.  N60AC.001:  Postapocalypse Now (Instructor:  Caitlin Scholl) TWTh 3-5:30

4.  N60AC.002:  Finding America, Founding America, Foundling America (Instructor:  Cory Merrill) TWTh 1-3:30

5.  N60AC.003:  Ethnic Modernisms and the Mapping of Human Rights (Instructor:  Irina Popescu) TWTh 10-12:30

6.  W60AC (online):  Boroughs and Barrios:  Moving In & Through New York City and Los Angeles (Instructor:  Karina Palau, nominated for AC Teaching Award).

Google Summer of Code

See flyer for more information.

Following the program, students present their research projects in the Cal Energy Corps Symposium to the university community and the public.

 

This year, placements are available at the Center for Carbon Removal, Imprint Energy, Clarity Movement Co. (an environmental tech startup out of the CITRIS Foundry), Power Standard Labs, and the Lawrence Berkeley National Lab; as well as abroad with Tec De Monterrey, in Mexico.

 

For more information, including how to apply, please visit their website at calenergycorps.berkeley.edu. Applications due March 30, 2018.

Comp Lit Summer R1B and AC courses

If you are looking for a summer R1B or AC course, we have you covered in Comp Lit!  We have two R1B and four 60AC courses, including our new online one (W60AC), so you can get your AC requirement done even if you are not in Berkeley this summer.  I include the info and some of the posters below; all are session D (July 2-August 10) except for the online course, which is session C (June 18-August 10).

 

1.  R1B.001:  Sea Changes in Film and Poetry (Instructor:  Simona Schneider) TWTh 1-3:30

2.  R1B.002:  Celebrity Status:  The Art of Being Famous (Instructor:  Johnathan Vaknin) TWTh 10-12:30

3.  N60AC.001:  Postapocalypse Now (Instructor:  Caitlin Scholl) TWTh 3-5:30

4.  N60AC.002:  Finding America, Founding America, Foundling America (Instructor:  Cory Merrill) TWTh 1-3:30

5.  N60AC.003:  Ethnic Modernisms and the Mapping of Human Rights (Instructor:  Irina Popescu) TWTh 10-12:30

6.  W60AC (online):  Boroughs and Barrios:  Moving In & Through New York City and Los Angeles (Instructor:  Karina Palau, nominated for AC Teaching Award).
